isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - DRIVETRAIN FAILURE ANALYSIS - TRANSMISSION COMPLAINTS

svcproc.title: VIBRATION
svcproc.para: Vibration is a condition which can be difficult to trace and isolate. The effects of vibration will cause transmission problems, even though it originates somewhere else in the system. Intermittent vibration can be isolated under specific conditions of engine idle, RPM, gear selection, load and speed. Constant vibration should vary with engine RPM, load and speed to provide clues to its source.

step1.para: A loose output shaft nut. Examine the splines of the output shaft for shiny areas which indicate end yoke movement.
A rough idling engine. This will produce pulsation and gear train vibration as mainshaft gears mesh with mating gears. This condition is referred to as noise in neutral or while idling.
Loose or broken engine mounts. Loose or broken mounts will produce a vibration that appears to be in the transmission.
Incorrect U-joint working angles, out of phase propeller shafts or shafts that are out of balance and excessive shaft length. These will contribute to a vibration complaint.
